body: If the chunk looks like a path (a series of non-whitespace characters sepparated by slashes) maybe suggest the files in `os.list`?
Should it be enabled globally or just within strings?

Globally. If you are typing `\\something\interesting\` I'd say 99 times out of 100 you are refering to a path. Even more likely in open code tbh (since a slash is a escape character in a string; also, this is triggered by tab, no?)
\ is only escape when before specific characters in Stata. But yes I agree globally is good.
Is it worth it to support spaces in file paths if the file path is quoted? Maybe for absolute file paths? Not 100% on whether it's worth the hassle, tho.

Depends how difficult it is.

On Fri, Aug 24, 2018 at 1:12 PM Mauricio Caceres Bravo <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Is it worth it to support spaces in file paths if the file path is quoted?
> Maybe for absolute file paths? Not 100% on whether it's worth the hassle,
> tho.

It might be helpful to look at ipython's implementation for this. We probably wouldn't want to completely search the filesystem beforehand to create the environment. So maybe search as they type?
Doesn't `<tab>` trigger completion? When the user presses tab, we simply return the results of `os.listdir(pathBeforeCursor)`, no? Maybe `glob(pathBeforeCursor)` if you want to be fancy
Well in Atom it's as if you had hit <kbd>tab</kbd> after every keypress.
I guess you're right, this could be very easy.
It just depends on being smart enough to realize when something is a path. I personally think it would be fine to always try to match the content of an open string with paths.

> Well in Atom it's as if you had hit tab after every keypress.

There has to be some type of delay for Atom showing kernel completions, right? Otherwise typing'd have a lag. In any case, that concern is already present for other completions. The issue I see is that we ought to match, at the very least:

```
local path /this/is/a/path
local path "/this is/a path"
local path \\remote\path
local path C:\Windows\path
```

What to do? For paths without spaces, `glob(code[code.rfind(' ')+1:]` ought to be enough, right? Less sure about quoted paths.

> `local path \\remote\path`

I'm unfamiliar with this?
`\\server` is how windows does remote paths.
Google foo is "UNC path" to learn all about it.
And you'd be able to do `os.listdir()` to get the contents of that path? Seems like it would be slow anyways...

Sure. If lag is a concern, we can limit this to local paths without spaces. However, not 100% what to do about detecting a path. I was thinking maybe `os.path.isdir` but I think that detects remote paths.

So, ``re.search(r"^([A-Z]:\\|/)")``?
(Can you have more than 26 drives on windows? Not even sure if it goes to AA, AB, etc. like with linux devices.)

- I think for nonquoted paths, the case insensitive matching of your regex is fine. 
- I'd be in favor of relaxing the character requirements for quoted strings. Maybe allow some punctuation like periods or commas. Maybe dependent on that OS's filename restrictions. Maybe require that the first character in the string is a letter or something.
- I also think it's important to substitute the value of globals in paths. I mean personally I use a global in 95% of paths that I write.
  We currently have the names of globals in memory, but this would entail also getting the values of globals in memory.

No idea about the drives.

> I think for nonquoted paths, the case insensitive matching of your regex is fine.

Great.

> I'd be in favor of relaxing the character requirements for quoted strings. Maybe allow some punctuation like periods or commas. Maybe dependent on that OS's filename restrictions. Maybe require that the first character in the string is a letter or something.

When do we match a path if something is quoted? I think maybe
```
s = regex.search(r'(?r)[^`]"(?<maybePath>([A-Z]:\\|/).*)\Z')
if s:
    maybePath = s.groupdict()["maybePath"]
```

Not sure that works...A proper way to do it is to figure out if you are inside a string via the tokenizer, right?

> I also think it's important to substitute the value of globals in paths. I mean personally I use a global in 95% of paths that I write.

Sure. Only one level of recursion or nested local/global name resolution?

> We currently have the names of globals in memory, but this would entail also getting the values of globals in memory.

One idea is to use a different log file for `_StataKernelCompletions` (so they don't appear in the main log or in any other log that might be open). Then we would simply regexp the value from that file, instead of having to re-run `macro dir` or whatever.

Another idea is to store both the local name and the values in `self.completions`.

> A proper way to do it is to figure out if you are inside a string via the tokenizer, right?

Yes. Hopefully that wouldn't take too long. All you need to know is strings and comments, which is essentially just the first-pass tokenizer already used.

> Only one level of recursion or nested local/global name resolution?

I think one level is fine.

> use a different log file for _StataKernelCompletions

This is definitely something to look into in general. It solve #154, which I think is important. But we'd have to be continually switching log files. And that might get messy.

> Another idea is to store both the local name and the values in self.completions.

For globals I think this is fine.

So I think the idea here is:

1. Store values of globals in memory
2. Determine when a string is a path
3. Substitute globals with their value
4. Use `os.listdir`

> A proper way to do it is to figure out if you are inside a string via the tokenizer, right?

I don't currently do it this way. This is a future improvement, because currently autocomplete won't work if there are spaces in the path, even if it's quoted.
